A.2 Proof of Lemma 3.3

[59] proved that the matrix 𝐆∞superscript𝐆\mathbf{G}^{\infty} is strictly positive definite. In their proof, 𝐆∞superscript𝐆\mathbf{G}^{\infty} is the covariance matrix of the functionals ψpsubscript𝜓𝑝\psi_{p} define as

ψp​(𝐯):=ϕ​(𝐯⊤​𝐱p)assignsubscript𝜓𝑝𝐯italic-ϕsuperscript𝐯topsubscript𝐱𝑝\psi_{p}(\mathbf{v}):=\phi\left(\mathbf{v}^{\top}\mathbf{x}_{p}\right)

over the Hilbert space 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} of L2​(N​(0,α2​𝐈))superscript𝐿2𝑁0superscript𝛼2𝐈L^{2}\left(N\left(0,\alpha^{2}\mathbf{I}\right)\right). 𝐆∗∞superscript𝐆absent\mathbf{G}^{*\infty} is strictly positive definite by showing that ψ1,⋯,ψN​Msubscript𝜓1⋯subscript𝜓𝑁𝑀\psi_{1},\cdots,\psi_{NM} are linearly independent, which is equivalent to that

c1​ψ1+c2​ψ2+⋯+cN​M​ψN​M=0​ in ​𝒱subscript𝑐1subscript𝜓1subscript𝑐2subscript𝜓2⋯subscript𝑐𝑁𝑀subscript𝜓𝑁𝑀0 in 𝒱\displaystyle c_{1}\psi_{1}+c_{2}\psi_{2}+\cdots+c_{NM}\psi_{NM}=0\text{ in }\mathcal{V} (26)

holds only for cp=0subscript𝑐𝑝0c_{p}=0 for all p𝑝p.

Let 𝐆i∞subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑖\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{i} denote the i𝑖i-th M×M𝑀𝑀M\times M block matrices on the diagonal of 𝐆∞superscript𝐆\mathbf{G}^{\infty}. Then we have

𝐆∗∞=d​i​a​g​(𝐆1∞,⋯,𝐆N∞).superscript𝐆absent𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝐆1⋯subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑁\displaystyle\mathbf{G}^{*\infty}=diag(\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{1},\cdots,\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{N}).

To prove that 𝐆∗∞superscript𝐆absent\mathbf{G}^{*\infty} is strictly positive definite, we will show that 𝐆i∞subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑖\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{i} is positive definite. Let us define

ψj,i∗​(𝐯):=ϕ​(𝐯⊤​𝐱j)​𝟙​{j∈ site ​i},j=1,⋯,M.formulae-sequenceassignsubscriptsuperscript𝜓𝑗𝑖𝐯italic-ϕsuperscript𝐯topsubscript𝐱𝑗1𝑗 site 𝑖𝑗1⋯𝑀\psi^{*}_{j,i}(\mathbf{v}):=\phi\left(\mathbf{v}^{\top}\mathbf{x}_{j}\right)\mathbbm{1}\{j\in\text{ site }i\},\quad j=1,\cdots,M.

Then, we are going to show that

c1​ψ1,i∗+c2​ψ2,i∗+⋯+cM​ψM,i∗=0subscript𝑐1subscriptsuperscript𝜓1𝑖subscript𝑐2subscriptsuperscript𝜓2𝑖⋯subscript𝑐𝑀subscriptsuperscript𝜓𝑀𝑖0\displaystyle c_{1}\psi^{*}_{1,i}+c_{2}\psi^{*}_{2,i}+\cdots+c_{M}\psi^{*}_{M,i}=0 (27)

holds only for cj=0,∀j∈[M]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑐𝑗0for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑀c_{j}=0,\forall j\in[M]. Suppose there exist c1,⋯,cMsubscript𝑐1⋯subscript𝑐𝑀c_{1},\cdots,c_{M} that are not identically 0, satisfying (27). Let the coefficients for client i𝑖i be c1,⋯,cMsubscript𝑐1⋯subscript𝑐𝑀c_{1},\cdots,c_{M} and let the coefficients for other client be 0. Then, we have a sequence of coefficients satisfying (26), which is a contradiction with that 𝐆∞superscript𝐆\mathbf{G}^{\infty} is strictly positive definite. This implies 𝐆i∞subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑖\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{i} is strictly positive definite. Namely, 𝐆i∞subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑖\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{i}’s eigenvalues are positive. Since the eigenvalues of 𝐆∗∞superscript𝐆absent\mathbf{G}^{*\infty} are exactly the union of the eigenvalues of 𝐆i∞subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑖\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{i}, λm​i​n​(𝐆∗∞)subscript𝜆𝑚𝑖𝑛superscript𝐆absent\lambda_{min}(\mathbf{G}^{*\infty}) is positive and thus, 𝐆∗∞superscript𝐆absent\mathbf{G}^{*\infty} is strictly positive definite.

A.3 Proof of Corollary 3.6

To compare the convergence rates of using aggregated BN and client-specific BN, we compare the exponential factor in the convergence rates, which are (1−η​e0/2)1𝜂subscript𝑒02\left(1-\eta e_{0}/2\right) and (1−η​e0∗/2)1𝜂subscriptsuperscript𝑒02\left(1-\eta e^{*}_{0}/2\right), respectively. Then, it reduces to comparing e0=λmin​(𝐆∞)subscript𝑒0subscript𝜆superscript𝐆e_{0}=\lambda_{\min}(\mathbf{G}^{\infty}) and e0∗=λmin​(𝐆∗∞)subscriptsuperscript𝑒0subscript𝜆superscript𝐆absente^{*}_{0}=\lambda_{\min}(\mathbf{G}^{*\infty}). Comparing equation (23) and (25), 𝐆∗∞superscript𝐆absent\mathbf{G}^{*\infty} takes the M×M𝑀𝑀M\times M block matrices on the diagonal of 𝐆∞superscript𝐆\mathbf{G}^{\infty}:

𝐆∞=[𝐆1∞𝐆1,2∞⋯𝐆1,N∞𝐆1,2∞𝐆2∞⋯𝐆2,N∞⋮⋮⋱⋮𝐆1,N∞𝐆2,N∞⋯𝐆N∞],superscript𝐆delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐆1subscriptsuperscript𝐆12⋯subscriptsuperscript𝐆1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐆12subscriptsuperscript𝐆2⋯subscriptsuperscript𝐆2𝑁⋮⋮⋱⋮subscriptsuperscript𝐆1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐆2𝑁⋯subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑁\mathbf{G}^{\infty}=\left[\begin{array}[]{cccc}\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{1}&\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{1,2}&\cdots&\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{1,N}\\ \mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{1,2}&\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{2}&\cdots&\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{2,N}\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ \mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{1,N}&\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{2,N}&\cdots&\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{N}\end{array}\right],
𝐆∗∞=[𝐆1∞0⋯00𝐆2∞⋯0⋮⋮⋱⋮00⋯𝐆N∞],superscript𝐆absentdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐆10⋯00subscriptsuperscript𝐆2⋯0⋮⋮⋱⋮00⋯subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑁\mathbf{G}^{*\infty}=\left[\begin{array}[]{cccc}\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{1}&0&\cdots&0\\ 0&\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{2}&\cdots&0\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ 0&0&\cdots&\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{N}\end{array}\right],

where 𝐆i∞subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑖\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{i} is the i𝑖i-th M×M𝑀𝑀M\times M block matrices on the diagonal of 𝐆∞superscript𝐆\mathbf{G}^{\infty}. By linear algebra,

λmin​(𝐆i∞)≥λmin​(𝐆∞),∀i∈[N].formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑖subscript𝜆superscript𝐆for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\lambda_{\min}(\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{i})\geq\lambda_{\min}(\mathbf{G}^{\infty}),\quad\forall i\in[N].

Since the eigenvalues of 𝐆∗∞superscript𝐆absent\mathbf{G}^{*\infty} are exactly the union of eigenvalues of 𝐆i∞subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑖\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{i}, we have

λmin​(𝐆∗∞)subscript𝜆superscript𝐆absent\displaystyle\lambda_{\min}(\mathbf{G}^{*\infty}) =mini∈[N]⁡{λmin​(𝐆i∞)},absentsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑁subscript𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝐆𝑖\displaystyle=\min_{i\in[N]}\{\lambda_{\min}(\mathbf{G}^{\infty}_{i})\},
≥λmin​(𝐆∞).absentsubscript𝜆superscript𝐆\displaystyle\geq\lambda_{\min}(\mathbf{G}^{\infty}).

Thus, (1−η​e0/2)≥(1−η​e0∗/2)1𝜂subscript𝑒021𝜂subscriptsuperscript𝑒02\left(1-\eta e_{0}/2\right)\geq\left(1-\eta e^{*}_{0}/2\right) and we can conclude that the convergence rate of using client-specific BN is faster than the convergence of using aggregated BN.

Appendix B Error Bound Analysis and Proofs

In this section, we first give the proofs for the Theorem 3.7, then we extend this bound for federated learning with multiple training clients, and at last, we introduce a corollary showing the new error bound with reduced divergence term by using our client-specific BN.

B.1 Proof of Theorem 3.7 and Corollary 3.8

First, we introduce notation for our error bound analysis on out-of-federation clients.

B.2 Corollary 3.9 of Reduced Error Bound by Using Client-specific BN

We first give the formal statement of the new error bound with reduced divergence term using our proposed client-specific BN.

Corollary B.1 (generalization bound with client-specific BN).

Under the assumptions of Theorem 3.7, the new generalization error for our method (f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}) is bounded as:

Ju​(fu∗)subscript𝐽𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑢\displaystyle J_{u}(f_{u}^{*}) ≤J^𝒩~​(∑i=1Nωi​fi∗)+∑i=1Nωi​ϵiabsentsubscript^𝐽~𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝜔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝜔𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\displaystyle\leq\widehat{J}_{\tilde{\mathcal{N}}}(\sum_{i=1}^{N}\omega_{i}f_{i}^{*})+\sum_{i=1}^{N}\omega_{i}\epsilon_{i} (31)
+4​2​d​log⁡(2​N​M)+log⁡(4/δ)N​M.42𝑑2𝑁𝑀4𝛿𝑁𝑀\displaystyle\quad+4\sqrt{\frac{2d\log\left(2NM\right)+\log\left({4}/{\delta}\right)}{NM}}.

The proof is given below, and the key idea is that, by using our client-specific BN, i.e., using the test statistics to normalize features, the divergence of the distributions of the normalized features between seen and unseen clients decreases. More specifically, if the input data are all Gaussian distributed, our method is tend to obtain the standard Gaussian distribution same as feature distributions during training, thus the divergence becomes zero.

As we assume that ℋℋ\operatorname{{\mathcal{H}}} is a class of two layer neural network with batch normalization, then the input data is transformed as:

𝐳:=(V​[W​𝐱])−1/2​(W​𝐱−𝔼​[W​𝐱]),assign𝐳superscript𝑉delimited-[]𝑊𝐱12𝑊𝐱𝔼delimited-[]𝑊𝐱\operatorname{{\mathbf{z}}}:=(V[W\mathbf{x}])^{-1/2}(W\mathbf{x}-\mathbb{E}[W\mathbf{x}]),

where W∈ℝd×m𝑊superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚W\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} and m𝑚m is the number of neurons. Since 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} is Gaussian distributed, the transformed layer 𝐳𝐳\operatorname{{\mathbf{z}}} follows 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}, where 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} is the standard Gaussian distribution with mean 𝟎0\mathbf{0} and covariance matrix as identity matrix. For ∀f∈ℋfor-all𝑓ℋ\forall f\in\operatorname{{\mathcal{H}}}, there exists a function q𝑞q such that q​(𝐳)=f​(𝐱;W)𝑞𝐳𝑓𝐱𝑊q(\operatorname{{\mathbf{z}}})=f(\mathbf{x};W) and for the true labeling function g𝑔g, let qt​(𝐳)=g​(𝐱;Wt)subscript𝑞𝑡𝐳𝑔𝐱subscript𝑊𝑡q_{t}(\operatorname{{\mathbf{z}}})=g(\operatorname{{\mathbf{x}}};W_{t}), where Wtsubscript𝑊𝑡W_{t} is the true model parameter. Thus, we have:

Js​(f)subscript𝐽𝑠𝑓\displaystyle J_{s}(f) =𝔼𝐱∼𝒩i​[ℓ​(f​(𝐱),g​(𝐱))]absentsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝒩𝑖delimited-[]ℓ𝑓𝐱𝑔𝐱\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{N}_{i}}[\ell(f(\mathbf{x}),g(\mathbf{x}))]
=𝔼𝐳∼𝒩​[ℓ​(q​(𝐳),qt​(𝐳))]=J𝒩​(q).absentsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐳𝒩delimited-[]ℓ𝑞𝐳subscript𝑞𝑡𝐳subscript𝐽𝒩𝑞\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\operatorname{{\mathbf{z}}}\sim\mathcal{N}}[\ell(q(\operatorname{{\mathbf{z}}}),q_{t}(\operatorname{{\mathbf{z}}}))]=J_{\mathcal{N}}(q).

For seen clients, the risk becomes J𝒩​(q)subscript𝐽𝒩𝑞J_{\mathcal{N}}(q) instead of J𝒩i​(f)subscript𝐽subscript𝒩𝑖𝑓J_{\mathcal{N}_{i}}(f), which means the covaraite shift is eliminated by BN.

For unseen client with proposed client-specific BN, the input data is transformed as 𝐳I:=Σt−1/2​(W​𝐱−μt)assignsubscript𝐳𝐼superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑡12𝑊𝐱subscript𝜇𝑡\operatorname{{\mathbf{z}}}_{I}:=\Sigma_{t}^{-1/2}(W\operatorname{{\mathbf{x}}}-\mu_{t}), where μtsubscript𝜇𝑡\mu_{t} and ΣtsubscriptΣ𝑡\Sigma_{t} are the mean and variance matrix calculated using the seen clients data. The client-specific BN reduces the divergence of distributions of the seen and unseen clients.

Appendix C Causal Analysis and Proofs

In this section we show how to achieve the intervention on F𝐹F via intervening the surrogate variable S𝑆S. The main proof sketch is using calculus of intervention to exchange the effect of intervening F𝐹F and S𝑆S. We start by presenting the challenges of using back-door adjustment in federated scenario. Then we demonstrate the proof our proposition, which provides a more simple and less costly way for federated testing.

C.1 Challenges of Back-door Adjustment in FL

In this section, we first explain why using back-door adjustment in to tackle issues in federated testing is challenging.

To conduct intervention on a certain vertex X𝑋X in the causal graph via back-door adjustment, the key idea is summing the conditional probability over a set of parent vertices of X𝑋X. Based on [32], we first define the valid adjustment set as following:

Definition C.1 (Valid adjustment set).

Consider an causal graph over variables 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} and let Y∉P​AX𝑌𝑃subscript𝐴𝑋Y\notin PA_{X} (otherwise we have P​(Y|d​o​(X))=P​(Y)𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑋𝑃𝑌P(Y|do(X))=P(Y)). We call a set 𝒟⊆𝒱\{X,Y}𝒟\𝒱𝑋𝑌\operatorname{{\mathcal{D}}}\subseteq\mathcal{V}\backslash\{X,Y\} a valid adjustment set for the ordered pair (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y) if:

P​(Y|d​o​(X))=∑𝐝P​(Y|X,𝐝)​P​(𝐝).𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑋subscript𝐝𝑃conditional𝑌𝑋𝐝𝑃𝐝P(Y|do(X))=\sum\nolimits_{\mathbf{d}}P(Y|X,\mathbf{d})P(\mathbf{d}). (32)

Here, the sum (could also be an integral) is over the range of 𝒟𝒟\operatorname{{\mathcal{D}}}, that is, over all values 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} that 𝒟𝒟\operatorname{{\mathcal{D}}} can take.

From the valid adjustment set definition, we can see that the intervention P​(Y|d​o​(X))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑋P(Y|do(X)) can be achieved by adjusting over all values 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} that 𝒟𝒟\operatorname{{\mathcal{D}}} can take. Before conducting the adjustment as shown in the right hand side of Eq.(32), we should make sure the left hand side intervention is identifiable, i.e., all variables in the graph should be measured, otherwise, the causal intervention P​(Y|d​o​(X))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑋P(Y|do(X)) is not computable. We give a theorem based on Chapter 3 [31] to illustrate the identifiabiltiy and the relationships between identifiabiltiy and adjustment as following:

Theorem C.2 (Identifiability).

Consider a causal graph over a subset 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} of variables are measured, the causal effect P​(Y|d​o​(X))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑋P(Y|do(X)) is identifiable whenever {X∪Y∪P​AX}⊆V𝑋𝑌𝑃subscript𝐴𝑋𝑉\left\{X\cup Y\cup PA_{X}\right\}\subseteq V, that is, whenever X𝑋X, Y𝑌Y, and all parents of variables in X𝑋X are measured. The expression P​(Y|d​o​(X))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑋P(Y|do(X)) is then obtained by adjusting for P​AX𝑃subscript𝐴𝑋PA_{X} as in Eq.(32).

From the Definition C.1 and Theorem C.2, we can summarize that to conduct a valid back-door adjustment for a pair (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y), we should satisfy two conditions:

  1. 1.

    The causal effect of P​(Y|d​o​(X))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑋P(Y|do(X)) is identifiable

  2. 2.

    The set of parent variables P​AX𝑃subscript𝐴𝑋PA_{X} for adjustment are valid.

In centralized context, there is no strict on data access, all data distributions in 𝒟𝒟\operatorname{{\mathcal{D}}} can be accessed. The intervention can be computed from the observational distribution and the graph structure, i.e., the causal graph is explicitly defined and all variables are measured. Therefore, two conditions are satisfied, making the intervention P​(Y|d​o​(X))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑋P(Y|do(X)) certainly identifiable and can be computed via back-door adjustment.

Considering our FL scenario, all variables are measured under the distributed paradigm, so the causal effect P​(Y|d​o​(X))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑋P(Y|do(X)) is identifiable. However, when we want to achieve the intervention by adjusting parent variables (i.e., 𝒟issubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑠𝑖\operatorname{{\mathcal{D}}}^{s}_{i}) of X𝑋X, since each client data is strictly kept locally, we cannot find a valid adjustment set for (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y). The second condition does not hold, making the back-door adjustment failed. To ensure a successful back-door adjustment, the variables 𝒟sisuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑖\operatorname{{\mathcal{D}}}_{s}^{i} need to be shared, which matches the design in some federated domain generalization methods [14, 15]. But these methods may raise the privacy concern and extra communication cost, compared with these methods, our client-specific BN is more simple and less costly to improve the federated testing on external clients.

C.2 Proof of Proposition 3.10

First, we introduce the d-separation [31], which helps to demonstrate the independency between variables in the causal graph. If two variables are independent, there is no causal effects between them, indicating that the intervention on one variable will not have effects on the other one.

Definition C.3 (d-separation).

Let A,B,C𝐴𝐵𝐶A,B,C be the three non-intersecting subsets of variables in a directed acyclic graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. For any path between two variables, a collider is a variable where arrows of the path meet head-to-head. A path from A𝐴A to B𝐵B is said to be blocked by C𝐶C if either a non-collider on the path is in C𝐶C, or there is a collider on the path and neither the collider nor its descendants are in C𝐶C. If all paths from A𝐴A to B𝐵B are blocked, then A𝐴A is d-separated from B𝐵B by C𝐶C, denoted by A⟂⟂B∣CA\perp\mkern-9.5mu\perp B\mid C.

Based on the d-separation, we can show different effects of intervention towards dependent or independent variables, so according to [32], we introduce the rules of intervention calculus as following:

Theorem C.4 (Rules of intervention calculus).

Given a directed acyclic graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} and disjoint subsets of variables X,Y,Z𝑋𝑌𝑍X,Y,Z and W𝑊W, let P​(⋅)𝑃⋅P(\cdot) stand for the probability distribution induced by that model, we have the following rules.

Rule 1 (Insertion/deletion of observations):

P​(Y∣Z,W,d​o​(X))=P​(Y∣W,d​o​(X)),𝑃conditional𝑌𝑍𝑊𝑑𝑜𝑋𝑃conditional𝑌𝑊𝑑𝑜𝑋\displaystyle P(Y\mid Z,W,do(X))=P(Y\mid W,do(X)),
if(Y⟂⟂Z∣X,W)𝒢X¯\displaystyle\quad if(Y\perp\mkern-9.5mu\perp Z\mid X,W)_{\mathcal{G}_{\overline{X}}}

Rule 2 (Intervention/observation exchange):

P​(Y∣d​o​(Z),W,d​o​(X))=P​(Y∣Z,W,d​o​(X)),𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑍𝑊𝑑𝑜𝑋𝑃conditional𝑌𝑍𝑊𝑑𝑜𝑋\displaystyle P({Y}\mid do(Z),W,do(X))=P({Y}\mid Z,{W},do(X)),
if(Y⟂⟂Z∣X,W)𝒢X¯​Z¯\displaystyle\quad if(Y\perp\mkern-9.5mu\perp Z\mid X,W)_{\mathcal{G}_{\overline{X}\underline{Z}}}

Rule 3 (Insertion/deletion of interventions):

P​(Y∣d​o​(Z),W​d​o​(X))=P​(Y∣W,d​o​(X)),𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑍𝑊𝑑𝑜𝑋𝑃conditional𝑌𝑊𝑑𝑜𝑋\displaystyle P({Y}\mid do(Z),{W}do(X))=P(Y\mid W,do(X)),
if(Y⟂⟂Z∣X,W)𝒢X¯,Z¯​(W)\displaystyle\quad if(Y\perp\mkern-9.5mu\perp Z\mid X,W)_{\mathcal{G}_{\overline{X},\overline{Z}(W)}}

Start from our formed causal graph for federated testing, the test-specific statistics S𝑆S (i.e., mean and variance of batch data in testset) is introduced and can be served as surrogate variable with following conditions satisfied: (1) F𝐹F intercepts all directed paths from S𝑆S to Y𝑌Y; and (2) P​(Y|d​o​(S))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑆P(Y|do(S)) is identifiable (according to Theorem C.2). The first condition makes sure the causal effect between S𝑆S and Y𝑌Y is indirect, i.e., S𝑆S affects Y𝑌Y totally through F𝐹F, otherwise, the effects of intervening S𝑆S and F𝐹F will both be passed to Y𝑌Y directly, we can not eliminate either one intervention. The second condition ensures the intervention P​(Y|d​o​(S))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑆P(Y|do(S)) can be computed over our graph.

Firstly, the Rule 3 of Theorem C.4 can be applied on original intervention P​(Y|d​o​(F))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝐹P(Y|do(F)), having:

P​(Y|d​o​(F))=P​(Y|d​o​(F),d​o​(S)),𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝐹𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝐹𝑑𝑜𝑆\displaystyle P(Y|do(F))=P(Y|do(F),do(S)), (33)
because(Y⟂⟂S∣F)𝒢F¯​S¯\displaystyle\quad because(Y\perp\mkern-9.5mu\perp S\mid F)_{\mathcal{G}_{\overline{F}\overline{S}}}

The Eq.(33) demonstrates that, due to the intervention on F𝐹F, variable F𝐹F is not be affected by its parent variable S𝑆S, so the external intervention d​o​(S)𝑑𝑜𝑆do(S) is independent from the label Y𝑌Y. With the independency between S𝑆S and Y𝑌Y, we can add S𝑆S holding any values into the conditional probability, having P​(Y|d​o​(F),d​o​(S))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝐹𝑑𝑜𝑆P(Y|do(F),do(S)).

Then, consider relations in 𝒢F¯​S¯subscript𝒢¯𝐹¯𝑆\mathcal{G}_{\underline{F}\overline{S}}, intervention on F𝐹F can be removed based on Rule 2, having:

P​(Y|d​o​(F),d​o​(S))=P​(Y|d​o​(S)),𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝐹𝑑𝑜𝑆𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑆\displaystyle P(Y|do(F),do(S))=P(Y|do(S)), (34)
because(Y⟂⟂S∣F)𝒢F¯​S¯\displaystyle\quad because(Y\perp\mkern-9.5mu\perp S\mid F)_{\mathcal{G}_{\underline{F}\overline{S}}}

This equation shows the conditions for an external intervention d​o​(S)𝑑𝑜𝑆do(S) to have same effect on Y𝑌Y as the passive observation S=s𝑆𝑠S=s (here s𝑠s is the mean and variance of test-specific data), since in 𝒢F¯​S¯subscript𝒢¯𝐹¯𝑆\mathcal{G}_{\underline{F}\overline{S}} all paths from S𝑆S to Y𝑌Y are eliminated. Combining Eq.(33) and Eq.(34), we finally conduct the intervention on F𝐹F with the help of surrogate variable S𝑆S,

P​(Y|d​o​(F))=P​(Y|d​o​(S)).𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝐹𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑆P(Y|do(F))=P(Y|do(S)). (35)

Combing the above conditions for introducing the surrogate variable S𝑆S and rules to exchange intervention, we have the proposition as below:

Proposition C.5.

With the causal graph defined for testing, if a variable S𝑆S served as surrogate variable with following conditions satisfied: (1)F𝐹F intercepts all directed paths from S𝑆S to Y𝑌Y; (2)P​(Y|d​o​(S))𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑆P(Y|{do}(S)) is identifiable; (3)(Y⟂⟂S|F)𝒢S¯​F¯t​e(Y\perp\mkern-9.5mu\perp S|F)_{\mathcal{G}^{te}_{\overline{S}\overline{F}}}; and (4)(Y⟂⟂F|S)𝒢S¯​F¯t​e(Y\perp\mkern-9.5mu\perp F|S)_{\mathcal{G}^{te}_{\overline{S}\underline{F}}}, then we have

P​(Y|d​o​(F))=P​(Y|d​o​(S)).𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝐹𝑃conditional𝑌𝑑𝑜𝑆P(Y|do(F))=P(Y|do(S)). (36)
